title: 106_s481
content: The Act titled "Environmental Crimes and Enforcement Act of 1999" allows for reimbursement of costs incurred by state, local, or tribal governments for assisting in federal investigations and prosecutions of environmental crimes. The Act "Environmental Crimes and Enforcement Act of 1999" amends Chapter 232 of title 18, United States Code, to allow reimbursement of State, local, or tribal government costs for assisting in Federal investigation and prosecution of environmental crimes defined under specific sections of various Acts. The Pollution Control Act amends various environmental Acts to address pollution prevention and enforcement. The Pollution Control Act amends environmental Acts to address pollution prevention and enforcement by requiring convicted individuals to reimburse State, local, or tribal governments for costs incurred in assisting with investigations and prosecutions. Amounts paid must be used solely for enforcing environmental laws. Conforming Amendment to chapter 232 of title 18, United States Code, regarding pollution prevention and enforcement. SEC. 3. Protection of government employees and the public from environmental crimes includes reimbursement of State, local, or tribal government costs for assistance in Federal investigation and prosecution of environmental crimes. Chapter 39 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include protection for government employees and the public from environmental crimes, defining environmental crimes as offenses punishable under various environmental acts. The curr_chunk discusses various sections of environmental acts such as the Clean Air Act and the Safe Drinking Water Act. The term 'organization' is defined as a legal entity organized for any purpose, including corporations, partnerships, and associations. 'Serious bodily injury' is defined as injury involving unconsciousness, extreme pain, disfigurement, or impairment of bodily functions. The penalty for an environmental crime that causes serious bodily injury or death includes imprisonment up to 20 years, a fine of up to $500,000, or both for individuals, and a fine of up to $1,000,000 for organizations. The penalty for an environmental crime causing serious bodily injury or death includes imprisonment up to 20 years and fines of up to $500,000 for individuals and up to $2,000,000 for organizations. SEC. 4. ENVIRONMENTAL CRIMES TRAINING FOR STATE, LOCAL, AND TRIBAL LAW ENFORCEMENT PERSONNEL. The Environmental Crimes Training Act of 1999 establishes a program called the "State, Local, and Tribal Environmental Enforcement Training Program" for law enforcement personnel, including inspectors, investigators, experts, regulators, lawyers, and police. The program is administered by the National Enforcement Training Institute of the Office of Criminal Enforcement, Forensics, and Training. The Environmental Crimes Training Act of 1999 establishes a program to train State, local, and tribal law enforcement personnel in investigating environmental crimes at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center in Glynn County, Georgia. SEC. 5. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS. Sec. 3296 of Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code, defines environmental crimes as offenses punishable under various environmental protection acts. The Safe Drinking Water Act, Solid Waste Disposal Act, Clean Air Act, Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act, Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act, and other specified laws outline limitations on prosecuting individuals for environmental crimes. The statute of limitations for prosecuting environmental crimes is 5 years after the offense is committed, or 8 years if the crime is concealed. SEC. 6. ATTEMPTS. Amendments are made to the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act and the Toxic Substances Control Act regarding attempts to commit offenses, subjecting individuals to the same penalties as prescribed for the offense. Amendments are made to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act regarding attempts to commit offenses, with individuals subject to the same penalties as prescribed for the offense. Amendments to various acts state that individuals attempting to commit offenses will face the same penalties as those prescribed for the offense. Amendments to the Clean Air Act state that individuals attempting to commit offenses will face the same penalties as those prescribed for the offense. SEC. 7. ENVIRONMENTAL CRIMES RESTITUTION. Section 3663(b) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include restitution for environmental offenses, requiring offenders to pay for removal, remediation, and restoration of the environment in cases of pollution or damage. The term 'victim' now includes municipalities or political subdivisions affected by the pollution or damage. SEC. 8. PREJUDGMENT ORDERS TO SECURE PAYMENT FOR ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE. Sec. 838 of Chapter 39 of title 18, US Code defines property to include real and personal property. The court can issue a prejudgment order to prevent the defendant from disposing of any property upon indictment for an environmental crime. The court can issue an order to prevent the defendant from disposing of any property if there is probable cause to believe it will hinder restitution for environmental violations. The United States must prove the projected cost for environmental cleanup in seeking an order, with the burden of proof on them. Defenses include having other assets for restitution or already making full restitution. The defendant must make full restitution, including environmental cleanup and restoration. Proceedings are governed by Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, and the court can amend the order at any time. The order expires upon dismissal or judgment entry. The court's powers under section 1651 of title 28 are not diminished. Prejudgment orders can be issued to secure payment for environmental damage under section 838.
